entry.title: Combined summary - Announcement: Full-RBF Miner Bounty
entry.summary: Bitcoin developer Peter Todd has launched a full-replace-by-fee (RBF) bounty program for miners to incentivize them to participate in the transition of Bitcoin to a more secure mempool policy based on economic incentives rather than trust. To join the program, miners can use the mempoolfullrbf=1 option in the upcoming Bitcoin Core v24 release or modify the code by removing the opt-in RBF check. Todd is also running some full-RBF peers to ensure that full-RBF nodes are interconnected and replacements can easily propagate. He has received donations and raised the reward to about 0.02 BTC or $400 USD at current prices.In a recent discussion on the bitcoin-dev mailing list, members discussed an attack on Bitcoin's opt-in replace-by-fee (RBF) and 0-conf usage. One proposed solution was to work on a Bitcoin core implementation that stops propagation of full-RBF replaced blocks. However, implementing such a rule could result in unintended chainsplits, and enforcing mempool consistency through consensus rules is not feasible. There have been suggestions made to enforce mempool consistency, although some warn that this could lead to unintended chain splits. The solution proposed by El_Hoy involves working on a Bitcoin Core implementation that stops propagation of full-rbf replaced blocks. Although implementing this option may be politically difficult as Petter Todd already has commit access to the main repository, it has been suggested that a sufficiently incentivized actor could work on a fork and run several nodes with such functionality.Todd started a full-RBF bounty program for miners, broadcasting full-RBF replacements with high fees to reward miners that turn on full-RBF. The rewards are starting small at just around $100/block in times of congestion, but he has received a few hundred dollars worth of donations and has raised the reward to about 0.02 BTC or $400 USD at current prices. Businesses that accept 0conf will have to adjust their risk accordingly, and misaligned incentives will be resolved. Bitcoin developer Peter Todd has launched a full-RBF bounty program for miners, offering rewards to those who turn on full-RBF by broadcasting full-RBF replacements paying high fees. This program aims to help transition Bitcoin to a more secure mempool policy based on economic incentives rather than trust. Miners interested in participating can use the mempoolfullrbf=1 option in the upcoming Bitcoin Core v24 release or modify the code themselves by removing the opt-in RBF check.A member of the bitcoin-dev community has set up a mempoolfullrbf=1 node and is logging replacement events in order to monitor them more closely. They are filtering full-RBF replacements and listing the replaced and replacement transactions on https://fullrbf.mempool.observer/. Another member of the community suggests that it would be helpful to list how long ago the replaced transaction was seen compared to the full RBF event timestamp, particularly for cases where the replaced tx was the one that was mined and how long after the full RBF event the block was received.In another discussion on the Bitcoin-dev mailing list, Erik Aronesty pointed out that technically, all that's needed is for miners to consistently mine "full RBF" transactions or the ones with the highest fee-rate. This can incentivize miners to mine transactions that double spend a previous transaction that isn't RBF. In response, Peter Todd announced a full-RBF bounty program for miners. The program involves broadcasting full-RBF replacements that pay extremely high fees to reward miners who turn on full-RBF, starting at $100 per block in times of congestion.Peter Todd, a Bitcoin developer, set up a mempoolfullrbf=1 node to monitor replacement events and is logging them. He filters the full-RBF replacements and lists the replaced and replacement transactions in his post. He has received donations and raised the reward to about 0.02 BTC or $400 USD at current prices. Todd has taken precautions to avoid double-spending transactions being mined by accident. In addition, he runs preferential peering patches to ensure that full-RBF nodes are interconnected with each other and replacements can easily propagate.Bitcoin developer Peter Todd has launched a full-replace-by-fee (RBF) bounty program for miners, which aims to incentivize them to turn on full-RBF. He is broadcasting replacements paying high fees to encourage miners to participate in the transition of Bitcoin to a more secure mempool policy based on economic incentives rather than trust. The profit margins for miners and pools are pretty small, making it easier to make a difference.
